results.title: The Hidden asset
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Womanpower”.
The developing countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America are mainly agricultural, with 85 percent of their people living on the land. Half of all this manpower is womanpower. But so far women’s economic contributions have been largely ignored while their labour has been taken for granted. The women of Sri Lanka are attempting to change this.

results.title: Equality and development
results.creator_credit: Elspeth MacDougall, Mark Robbins, Edward Magruder Jones and United Nations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Womanpower”.
Made during International Women’s Year, 1975, this film is about an International Women’s Forum discussing equal rights for women. In Tunisia, small changes have begun, but more is needed. Women need more education, and employment opportunities; to eradicate illiteracy and teach family planning. The cities and amusements belong to the men - this is to be changed.

results.title: A Woman's place is...
results.creator_credit: Elspeth MacDougall, Edward Magruder Jones and United Nations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Womanpower”.
This film was made during the International Women’s Year, 1975 and focuses on Sweden as an example of committed government using the full range of tools at its disposal in a real attempt to give substance to equality for women as set down in the United Nations Charter. Discusses women’s role in the workforce, sexism in the advertising world, men’s role in parenting and sharing house duties, educating primary aged children about gender roles and stereotyping, and basically highlighting the need for equality in all areas of life. Narrated by Joyce Gordon.

results.title: The Wind in the willows
results.creator_credit: Mark Hall, Brian Cosgrove and Cosgrove-Hall Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wind in the Willows Series”.
An enchanting puppet musical that captures the beauty of the English countryside and a way of life that disappeared with the decline of the British Empire. The film features favourite characters; Rat, Mole, Badger and Toad of Toad Hall. Based on the story by Kenneth Grahame and adapted by Rosemary Anne Sisson.

results.title: River red gum
results.creator_credit: Dione Gilmour, Michael Vance, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victoria. Ministry for Conservation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wildlife Australia”.
Shows the river red gum in its natural habitat, sheltering caterpillars, tiny marsupial carnivores, mistletoe birds, spitfires and saw flies. Also contains unique footage of ants farming slow-witted caterpillars for their sweet sticky secretions, in a three way business arrangement with the tree.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dione Gilmour, Michael Vance, ABC-TV (Australia) and Victoria. Ministry for Conservation

results.title: Creek and billabong
results.creator_credit: Dione Gilmour, Michael Vance and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wildlife Australia”.
Observes insect, bird and animal life around creeks and billabongs-the metamorphosis of a grublike mudeye into a dragonfly, yabbies, a kingfisher begging a meal from another kingfisher, a caddis fly building itself a sort of flying fortress to swim about in - and explains with superb close-ups, why wrigglers wriggle. The interrelationship of creatures living in these two aquatic environments, and the food chains of animal life found in freshwater are shown. Depicts the metamorphosis of the dragon-fly and the mosquito and looks at the caddis-fly, yappy, platypus, Murray cod and the water-rat.

The interrelationship of creatures living in these two aquatic environments, and the food chains of animal life found in freshwater are shown. Depicts the metamorphosis of the dragon-fly and the mosquito and looks at the caddis-fly, yappy, platypus, Murray cod and the water-rat.

results.title: Camel
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wildlife Australia”.
A study of the history of the camel in Australia and the way the animal has adapted to the environment. Corrects some of the popular misconceptions about the camel and its habitat and shows people who work with them in the outback. Two other introduced species - horses and donkeys - are also mentioned.
